December, Barack Obama reportedly called the owner of the Philadelphia Eagles to support the team's willingness to give Michael Vick a second chance. The Eagles' commitment to Michael Vick has been clear since they signed him in 2009: If a person made a terrible mistake and then paid their debts to society, was deeply remorseful and turned their life around completely... would you be willing to help this human being move forward? Despite these public displays of support, Michael Vick has faced intense scrutiny and criticism since his 2007 arrest and conviction for a series of crimes related to dog fighting. Kimberly Strassel, it's not that. "At the heart of Mr. Donald Rumsfeld 's book is an important critique of the Bush administration that has been largely missing from the debate over Iraq," Strassel writes. The dominant narrative to date has been that a cowboy president and his posse of neocons went to war without adequate preparation and ran roughshod over doubts by more sober bureaucratic and strategic minds. But what Donald Rumsfeld described in his memoir is a tale of mismanagement, "one that holds individuals"- but not necessarily Donald Rumsfeld himself- "responsible for failures of execution," Strassel writes.
